claim: I was 20 years old ten years ago, now I’m 30

supporting.text: If you were 20 years old ten years ago, adding 10 years to that age would logically make you 30 now.

attacks.text: If you were 20 years old ten years ago, adding 10 years to that age would logically make you 30 now.
Age calculation assumes no time anomalies or errors in memory, which could invalidate the result.
The claim relies on the assumption that the person's birth year is accurately known and consistent.
Time anomalies are purely hypothetical and not supported by empirical evidence.
Birth records and personal memory are generally reliable for age calculation in normal circumstances.

supporting.text: Basic arithmetic confirms that 20 + 10 equals 30, supporting the claim.

attacks.text: Basic arithmetic confirms that 20 + 10 equals 30, supporting the claim.
The claim assumes the person's age was accurately recorded ten years ago, which may not be true.
Birth records and official documents typically verify age, making inaccuracies unlikely.
Time perception can be subjective; the 'ten years ago' reference might not be exact.
Standard calendar measurements are objective, making subjective time perception irrelevant here.

supporting.text: Unless there is a time anomaly or miscalculation, the claim follows standard age progression.

attacks.text: Unless there is a time anomaly or miscalculation, the claim follows standard age progression.
Human memory is fallible, and the speaker might be misremembering their age ten years ago.
Time anomalies, though rare, cannot be entirely ruled out without further evidence.
Studies show that people generally remember their own age accurately over such short periods.
